title: 109_s765
content: The Act titled "Math and Science Incentive Act of 2005" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 contains findings related to the Act. Congress finds that the United States needs a robust scientific and technical enterprise, requiring more scientists and engineers. The education system must encourage students to study science and mathematics, as current performance lags behind international peers. The US must recommit to investing in research and development to secure a prosperous future. The United States needs to recommit to leadership in science, mathematics, and engineering, including nanotechnology advancements. A program of loan forgiveness can attract students to careers in these fields and help maintain technological leadership. Establishment of program for loan forgiveness to attract students to careers in science, mathematics, and engineering fields. The Secretary will implement a program to cover interest payments on loans for undergraduate students who meet specific criteria outlined in the Act. Under the program, undergraduate students meeting certain criteria, such as being new borrowers and teachers in STEM fields, can have their interest payments covered by the Secretary for loans obtained as undergraduates. Under the program, undergraduate students meeting specific criteria can have their interest payments covered by the Secretary for loans obtained as undergraduates. Participants must complete 5 consecutive years of service in a designated position to qualify. The Secretary will not make payments for interest that accrues before the repayment period begins or before the agreement is signed. Eligible applicants will be selected for the program by the Secretary. The Secretary will select participants for the program based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs of the United States, as well as academic record or job performance. The Secretary will select participants for the program based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs of the United States, as well as the academic record or job performance of the applicant. Eligible applicants may be chosen based on the likelihood of completing the 5-year service obligation, remaining in science, mathematics, or engineering after the service requirement, or other relevant criteria determined by the Secretary. The Secretary will select participants for the program based on national security, homeland security, and economic security needs of the United States, as well as the academic record or job performance of the applicant. Eligible applicants may be chosen based on the likelihood of completing the 5-year service obligation, remaining in science, mathematics, or engineering after the service requirement, or other relevant criteria determined by the Secretary. Loan interest payments are subject to appropriations, with priority given to individuals who received payments in the previous fiscal year. The Secretary is authorized to prescribe necessary regulations for this section. The Secretary prioritizes qualified applicants who received interest payments in the previous fiscal year. Regulations may be prescribed to carry out this section. Interest payments cover the period from the agreement's effective date, through service completion, up to either loan repayment completion, $10,000 payment by the Secretary, or if the borrower stops fulfilling the service. The agreement under subsection (a)(2)(E) continues after service completion and ends when the loan is repaid, $10,000 is paid by the Secretary, borrower stops fulfilling the service, or borrower's income exceeds 4 times the national per capita income for 6 months. The Secretary will repay the interest accrued on loans of student borrowers selected under subsection (a) based on income thresholds set at 4 times the national per capita income. Eligible individuals must apply for repayment. The Secretary will pay the interest that accrues on loans of student borrowers selected under subsection (a). Eligible individuals must submit an application for loan interest payment, including an agreement to repay if they fail to complete the required service. The application for loan interest payment includes an agreement to repay the Secretary if the individual fails to complete the required service. Consolidation loans may qualify for interest payment if used to repay specific types of loans. The borrower may receive loan interest payment only for loans used to repay specific types of loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965 or the National and Community Service Act of 1990 to prevent double benefits. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education, and "mathematics, science, or engineering professional" is defined as someone with a degree in science, mathematics, or engineering working in a related field, including as a professor at a higher education institution. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal year 2006 and the following 5 years to implement this Act.
